selected_quotes: The influence of journal submission guidelines on reporting of statistics and use of open research practices
Everyone always says someone (journals, funders, etc.) should do something to encourage these practices - here it is…
Effect of journal submission guidelines on authors' reporting of statistics and use of open research practices
To what extent are journal editors able to influence statistical practices in their journal?
Journal policies on open research may encourage desirable changes in authors' practices, Research in PLOS-1,

citation.abstract: From January 2014, Psychological Science introduced new submission guidelines that encouraged the use of effect sizes, estimation, and meta-analysis (the "new statistics"), required extra detail of methods, and offered badges for use of open science practices. We investigated the use of these practices in empirical articles published by Psychological Science and, for comparison, by the Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, during the period of January 2013 to December 2015. The use of null hypothesis significance testing (NHST) was extremely high at all times and in both journals. In Psychological Science, the use of confidence intervals increased markedly overall, from 28% of articles in 2013 to 70% in 2015, as did the availability of open data (3 to 39%) and open materials (7 to 31%). The other journal showed smaller or much smaller changes. Our findings suggest that journal-specific submission guidelines may encourage desirable changes in authors' practices.
citation.title: The influence of journal submission guidelines on authors' reporting of statistics and use of open research practices

news.title: Journals’ statistics rules ‘help tackle reproducibility crisis’
news.summary: Academic journals may be able to help tackle science’s reproducibility crisis by issuing guidelines on the use of statistics in papers submitted for publication, researchers say.
